entry.et: Middle English, from Old English būtan, preposition & conjunction, outside, without, except, except that; akin to Old High German būzan without, except; akin to Old English be by, ūt out by, out

def.dt: :except for the fact would have protested but that he was afraid
:that used after a negative there is no doubt but he won
:without the concomitant that it never rains but it pours
:if not :unless
:than no sooner started but it stopped not often in formal use
:on the contrary :on the other hand :notwithstanding used to connect coordinate elements he was called but he did not answer not peace but a sword
:yet poor but proud
:with the exception of used before a word often taken to be the subject of a clause none but the brave deserves the fair John Dryden
:that used after a negative there is no doubt but that it must be done
:that … not used to indicate possibility or uncertainty I don't know but what I will go
:with the exception of :barring no one there but me compare but 2c
:other than this letter is nothing but an insult
:without lacking
:outside
:only merely he is but a child
:outside
:to the contrary who knows but that she may succeed

dt.un: used as an intensive get there but fast

def.dt: :that not :who not nobody but has his fault Shakespeare
:the kitchen or living quarters of a 2-room cottage
:except for
:very nearly :almost would be all but impossible
:can not
:to be unable to do otherwise than we cannot but wonder why
